comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: It is difficult to be certain that it is the same person, but there was a Lionel O'Gorman Acton in the King's Liverpool Regiment, e.g.: From the London Gazette, 16 May 1917, p. 4763: "War Office, 16th May 1917. REGULAR FORCES. [...] The undermentioned cadets to be temp. 2nd Lts. (attd.). 26th Apr. 1917. INFANTRY. [...] L'pool R.-- Lionel O'Gorman Acton. Thomas Hanson Averill. Arthur Harold Morris. Herbert Thomas Jones. Alexander Spears. Frederick Bruce Walker. Edward Newell Goldspink." www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/30073/supplements/4763/ The National Archives, WO 339/75542: discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/SearchUI/details/C11293...

comment._content: Lionel W O'G A Acton marriage registered to Dorothy C. Keyse 4th qr 1919 in Greenwich Interestingly, Lionel W O A Acton, mother Wilkinson, birth registered 3rd qr 1952 in Folkestone www.freebmd.org.uk

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: William Lionel O'Gorman ADAMS-ACTON 1882-1943 Born: 103 Marylebone Road, Marylebone, London, England Died: Winterton, Charing Hill, Charing, Kent, England Baptism 1882 St Marylebone St Mark, Middlesex, England Residence 1901 St Marylebone, London, England 1911 St Marylebone, London, England Marriage: Church Of St Peter 1919 Deptford, Kent, England Residence 1919 Paddington and St Marylebone, England Death 1943 Winterton, Charing Hill, Charing, Kent, England Cause of death: 1. Tuberculosis Of The Lungs. 2. Myocarditis There is a family photograph - himself, wife and two sons? - posted here also. Family members: Father John ADAMS-ACTON 1831-1910 Mother Marion Jean Catherine HAMILTON 1846-1928 Brother John Harold George Ahloowalia ADAMS-ACTON 1876- Sister Dulcie Jean Helen Catherine ADAMS-ACTON 1878- Sister Monica Mary Kathleen ADAMS-ACTON 1879-1954 Brother Hamilton Douglas Harton ADAMS-ACTON 1882-1935 Brother Jerome Gladstone Murray ADAMS-ACTON 1886-1971 Sister Imogen Roma Sybil ADAMS-ACTON 1890- Wife Dorothy Catherine KEYSE 1896-1977 Son Ian A ADAMS-ACTON 1921-1927 Son Andrew John ADAMS-ACTON 1923-1981 Daughter Rita Mary ADAMS-ACTON 1926-1997 Son Murray ADAMS-ACTON 1927-1944 Son Leo Samuel ADAMS-ACTON 1929-1951 Posted by Monica Adams Acton www.uk.mundia.com/gb/Search/Results?givenName=&birthP... (family tree) William Lionel Adams-Acton birth recorded 2nd qr 1882 in Marylebone William L O Adams-Acton death recorded 3rd qr 1943 age 61 in Ashford www.freebmd.org.uk

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: His mother Marian Jean Catherine Adams-Acton (21 June 1846 – 11 October 1928) was a Scottish novelist. Most of her fiction was written under the pseudonym "Jeanie Hering". As the mother of six she undertook a journey of 500 miles in about 7 weeks from Arran to Dorset, with the poor nurse Ellen having to push the one-year-old in a perambulator. The story of the journey became her last book, being published in 1894 as Adventures of a Perambulator. "All Jeanie's boys survived the war." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marion_Adams-Acton His father John Adams-Acton was a famous sculptor. A sister of John, "Clarissa, engaged in art and exhibited at the Royal Academy. To avoid confusion with other artists of the same name, Adams adopted in 1869 the additional surname of Acton from his birthplace. "He executed the Wesley memorial in Westminster Abbey, the Cruikshank memorial in St. Paul's Cathedral, the statue of Wesley before the City Road chapel, and the memorial of Cardinal Manning in the new Roman Catholic Cathedral at Westminster. He also executed a colossal statue of Sir Titus Salt, erected near Bradford Town Hall in 1874, and statues of Queen Victoria for Kingston and the Bahamas, of Mr. Gladstone, a close friend and the godfather of his fourth son, for Blackburn and Liverpool, and of Bishop Waldegrave for Carlisle Cathedral. Edward VII, as Prince of Wales, sat to him many times, and the Emperor and Empress Frederick of Germany showed interest in his art. He exhibited regularly at the Royal Academy till 1892, sending there statues or busts of Gladstone (1865, 1868, 1869, 1873, 1879), Lord Brougham (1867, 1868), John Bright (1870), Charles Dickens (1871), Charles Spurgeon (1874), Earl Russell (1874), Archbishop Manning (1884), the earl of Beaconsfield (1885), and Leo XII (1888). Others who sat to him were Canon Duckworth, Lord Shaftesbury Dr. Parker, Mr. Fawcett, Lord Napier of Magdala, Cobden, Lord Roberts, Dean Farrar, Sir Wilfrid Lawson, Sir Isaa Holden, Sir Edwin Landseer, and many leading academicians. Of his ideal work the best were The First Sacrifice,' 'The Lady of the Lake,' 'Pharaoh's Daughter, 'Zenobia,' and 'The Millennium.' "Acton's last work, which was left unfinished, was a small figure of 'The Ange of Peace.' He died at his wife's home Ormidale, Brodick, in the Isle of Arran which he visited every summer, on 28 Oct 1910. "Acton married on 15 Aug. 1875, at St. Mark's Church, Hamilton Terrace, London Marion Hamilton of the Isle of Arran, an authoress writing under the name 'Jeannie Hering.' He had four sons and three daughters. Two of his sons, Harold and Murray, practised their father's art." Dictionary of National Biography, 1912 Supplement en.wikisource.org/wiki/Adams-Acton,_John_%28DNB12%29

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: A son died in WII: Pvt Murray Adams-Acton Birth: unknown Death: Aug. 22, 1944 Note: Private, 12th (10th Battalion, The Green Howards [Yorkshire Regiment]) Battalion, Parachute Regiment, A.A.C. (Served as ACTON). Son of Lionel William O'Gorman Adams-Acton and Dorothy Catherine Adams-Acton, of Hythe, Kent. Age: 17. Burial: Ranville War Cemetery Ranville Departement du Calvados Basse-Normandie, France Plot: VIA. B. 14. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=56095411 IWM War Memorials Archive www.ukniwm.org.uk/server/show/conMemorial.50071/fromUkniw... Another son died in North Korea: Leo Samuel ADAMS-ACTON (photo provided) Birth 1929 Thanet, Surrey, Kent Death 1951 North Korea (this is in error - he was captured 1951, killed 16 July 1953, awarded the MC posthumously) www.ww2escapelines.co.uk/youngelms/evasion/) Cause of death: Shot While Attempting To Escape From Prisoner Of War Camp In North Korea. Posted by MonicaAdamsActon www.uk.mundia.com (family tree) Gazetted 13 April 1954. LT A S (L S) ADAMS ACTON IWM War Memorials Archive www.ukniwm.org.uk/server/show/conMemorial.33462/fromUkniw...

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: It appears that the son served as Private Murray Acton, and died at the (horribly young) age of 17; there is some more information on his short career as a parachutist at: www.paradata.org.uk/people/murray-acton His CWGC casualty record can be found at: www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/2847455/ADAMS-ACTON,%... And a photograph of the grave at: twgpp.org/information.php?id=2295796

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: I'm not keen on posting links to living descendants, but it appears that Lionel's second son, Andrew Adams-Acton, was an airline navigator that emigrated to Australia in 1965. There is a short account of this from Lionel's grandson (also named Lionel) on the Australian Immigration Place website: www.immigrationplace.com.au/www/248/1040427/displayarticl...;

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: It is pure speculation, but it's possible that the O'Gorman middle name was derived from the contacts of Lionel's father with James Patrick Mahon (1800-91), an Irish politician and traveller that called himself the O'Gorman Mahon: www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/scrc/findingaids/view.php?eadid=IC... See also Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Patrick_Mahon
